For example, the American writer Bill Bryson notes that English weather is not very exciting, so the obsession seems strange: ‘To an outsider, the most striking thing about the English weather is that there is not very much of it. All those phenomena that elsewhere give nature an edge of excitement, unpredictability and danger – tornadoes, monsoons, raging blizzards, huge hailstorms – are almost wholly unknown in the British Isles.’ English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson and argues that English weather is interesting because of its unpredictability. ‘Bryson misses the point. The English fixation with the weather is nothing to do with deep emotion – like the English countryside, it is, for the most part, dramatically undramatic. The interest is less in the phenomena themselves but in its uncertainty…one of those things you can say about England with absolute certainty is that it has a lot of weather. It may not include tropical cyclones, but life at the edge of an ocean and the edge of a continent means you can never be entirely sure what you are going to get.’ My research shows that both Bryson and Paxman are missing the point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather at all. English weather-talk is a kind of code that helps English people overcome their natural shyness and talk to each other. Everyone knows that phrases like ‘Nice day, isn’t it?’ or ‘Ooh, isn’t it cold?’ are not requests for weather information. They are greetings, conversation starters, or fillers to keep the conversation going. English weather-talk is like ‘grooming talk’ – similar to how monkeys and apes groom each other to bond socially. There are specific situations where weather-talk is used. Some writers say that English people talk about the weather all the time, but this is not true. In fact, there are three main situations where weather-talk is used: as a simple greeting, as an ice-breaker to start a conversation, or as a ‘default’ topic when there is an awkward silence. This does mean there is a lot of weather-talk, so outsiders might think English people talk about nothing else. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, move to more weather-talk to break the ice, and then return to weather-talk if the conversation slows down. It is easy to see why people from other countries, and even some English writers, think English people are obsessed with the weather.'

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were already interested, as they had chosen this trip over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not satisfying. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to add context and interest to life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching after 31 years, Alice started a new career as an author in 2001. 

Alice found writing both exciting and challenging, but less exhausting than teaching. Her former colleagues envied her because she stayed connected with children through her books. Alice's main goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children's fiction today. She notes that much of adolescent fiction deals with negative experiences or is total fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books are different. Alice always tried to teach English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy," and she is motivated by her love for children. She enjoys the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. 

Alice sees her writing as an extension of teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also recommended a creative writing course, which surprised her. Although she had been teaching for 25 years, she was encouraged to attend the course. Before being accepted, she had to send her best piece of fiction, which she wrote quickly, creating a story about a Roman couple. The course participants gave her excellent feedback and suggested she publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as evidence of her writing skills, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, a critic and editor, helped her edit the novel. Alice says they complement each other, as he helps refine her writing while she focuses on adding new scenes.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to compete in a special race. The race would be man against car, and brother against brother. In the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same point. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be able to sit in the car and stay warm.’ Alistair was also eager. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair was dressed in full winter cycling gear. The cold didn’t bother him. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’s even going to make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’

The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, about 350 meters up. This was no problem for the car, but Alistair’s first couple of miles involved a steep 25 percent incline, so he had a tough start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sprinted away on his bike, heading for a track going straight up the hill and then across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny jumped in the car and was soon on the road. The next time the brothers would see each other would be at the finish line. The only question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s early confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first obstacle: a giant tractor moving out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he complained to the cameraman in the back of his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s all down to this farmer!’ After tense moments, Jonny got past the tractor and continued driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been there since before cars were invented, and the roads were not made for speed. Jonny tried to navigate a very narrow corner. The car slowed to a crawl, then passed through a stream on the road. Once clear of the last village, the car was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final straight to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping… and then a squeal of brakes as he reached the line. 

Finally, Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the waiting crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms in victory. ‘Yes!’ Minutes later, the car arrived, and Jonny stepped out. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel separated from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the contest and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but as if from far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people around the arena or the millions watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my lifelong coach, taught me early on that this was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost twice against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The 2006 defeat wasn’t so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer beat me easily, more easily than if I’d believed in myself more. But losing in 2007 left me very upset. I knew I could have done better; it wasn’t my ability that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and waste it. Toni, a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. But seeing how upset I was, he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete’s career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my grief, but he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; this time, my mindset would not fail me. The best sign that my mindset was right was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family, friends, and team members the night before the final, at the house we rent for Wimbledon, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid them from mentioning it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. From then until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

Text: A young, idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. Her name was Jane Goodall. In 1963, Britain’s National Geographical Society helped make Jane Goodall famous by producing articles and TV documentaries about her chimpanzee research. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. Ironically, her fame might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles, interviews, and books have told her life story, but they often focus on limited and sentimental aspects. She has been portrayed as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman dreaming of life with wild animals, and a determined feminist. These images can undervalue her actual work. Based on references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her 40-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a pioneering figure in her field and a leading zoologist. Her achievement can be simply stated: she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before Goodall, wild chimpanzees were seen as dangerous, and their behavior was misunderstood. No one knew they ate meat or used tools. We didn't realize they shared emotions with humans or had social systems like ours. We wouldn't have believed that chimpanzee communities had different cultural traditions. Goodall’s book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is the most authoritative work in this area, like an encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements by biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall helped change how we study animals and how humans think about themselves. Even as a child, there were signs of the person she would become. One clear example from her childhood was in 1939 when she was five. One autumn day, Jane disappeared. The police and neighbors searched for her. After a frantic search, she reappeared with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked where she had been. Jane explained she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to find out. This moment is seen as the start of her career as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me using the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.’ Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors, even some very famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many of them probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it than that. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley joined a drama course planning a standard acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon soundtrack. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes a range of things from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound enthusiastic about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a huge difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists put them together.’ She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone considering a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many dream about as kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more realistic jobs, like becoming a tax lawyer or making auto parts. The idea that you can make a living by drawing doodles like those in school notebooks seems silly. Yet, some people do just that. People don’t become cartoonists in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, after a typical cartoonist’s childhood (loving comic strips, contributing to school publications, being known as ‘the kid who draws’), I studied graphic design in college. After graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and in a few months, I was earning enough to support myself. You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, much money, or even to know how to draw well. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical barriers are low, but it’s still a tough job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t turn down any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything. But what about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is mostly an entrepreneurial activity – you have to create and sell your work. The more comfortable you are with this, the better you’ll do. I’ve seen cartoonists with average talent and great business skills do better than artistic geniuses. It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright’, put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it’s not a disaster – it can be a very lucky break!'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and clearing out old things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate getting rid of things, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me, looking confused. ‘You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?’ he asked. I said I was, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said ‘Yes’. We went our separate ways. In the years that followed, I felt a constant regret for what I’d done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. That’s how I felt when I opened an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He said: ‘I’ve got your electric guitar.’ It had been bought and sold several times since the man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He knew it was probably old, but he used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I almost cried. I would have given Keith anything he asked for, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad’s habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange series of events! My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I couldn’t make much progress. So I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I took my old guitar out of the box Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Picking it up again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I held it sitting down, then felt the need to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because the electric guitar is played this way. My fingers knew where to go. I couldn’t draw a diagram of the chords, but my hands just played them. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll have to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe I can play with him. Or maybe there are others my age who have had a similar experience. Maybe we could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, whom I interviewed many of, will tell you that sleep is crucial for our mental, physical, and social well-being. Those who struggle to sleep often understand its importance the most. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, cutting off the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage rich in dreams. Our most vivid and emotionally powerful dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests dreams have a purpose. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research on the brain did not support this idea. The study of dreams shifted to focus more on their physical origins rather than psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard University sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than people at his sleep center. He concluded that dream use increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams since films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Doesn't everyone – like teachers, software designers, and politicians – need to think creatively? Dreams, according to Stickgold, help us combine things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They 'ignore the obvious and put together things that make a kind of unexpected sense ... This is what creativity is,' says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to give some kind of fluency, fuel for thought. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can barely keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we deal with relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a beautiful sea view, there are empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Despite her talent, she doesn't keep any of her own work. 'As soon as I finish them, they go,' she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the originals could sell for millions, her reproductions sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie keeps her clients' names private, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but status is often important. One celebrity likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh.' 'Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,' she says. 'That's their choice.' Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie's copy. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her reproductions look as authentic as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have done it, she has never been tempted. People who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie isn't wealthy and has faced difficulties, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation doesn't make sense. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was good training for her current work and gave her a love for plants, but it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad she found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask for advice, Susie stresses the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to achieve her skills. Her training allows her to do anything from drawing plants to making perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas as her favorites. Susie says people often think modern art is easy, almost like children's work. Impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful, which is hard to do well. Given her skills, it's surprising that Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? And could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training and practice, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—good, but not exceptional. Perhaps it's like living on simple food after enjoying meals by a top chef. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing days, nothing was more important to Ellen MacArthur than the sea, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing from a young age. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a non-stop, solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and workspace for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even down to the number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly showed her stock of freeze-dried food, the small gas stove, and the neatly organized medical supplies and rations. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, she sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. She realized things she hadn't considered before. Seeing abandoned whaling stations felt like a warning. "It seemed like we just took what we wanted and moved on. That's what we do," she said. When I visited Ellen's office, she had just finished a heated conference call. She explained why we must act now to save the planet. "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find a way not to use them up. At first, my message was negative – use less – but then I saw another way." Now she focuses on re-using, talking passionately about things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says. "But I love learning. [The current situation] became something I couldn't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is different. It's about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It is part of who I am. You are so connected to everything around you. You don't have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. [My new] message will never be as simple as saying: 'I'm going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I've ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. As many young people spend more time on computers and video games, he hopes to inspire them to climb their own mountains or at least spend more time outside. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero,' and climbing Everest is just part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest points on each continent. Few people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he turns twenty.

I have talked to several experienced Everest climbers, and none of them think taking a 13-year-old up the world’s highest mountain is a good idea. They agree that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they doubt if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also question if a young person has enough experience to make the good decisions needed for such a dangerous climb. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. ‘I know that criticism is out there,’ Paul says, ‘but I can’t waste my time with it – there’s still so much to do. I think about possible problems, obviously. Karen and I weigh up the risks all the time, but we believe our own experience as climbers will help. And watching Jordan develop gives me confidence. He’s becoming so strong and grown-up.’

I also wonder about Jordan’s motivation. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his own love of adventure too far? ‘This project isn’t about me trying to become famous for my son’s achievements,’ Paul insists. ‘At first, he talked about it as something to do later in life, but when we discussed it, we thought: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him regularly to make sure he hasn’t lost the motivation to do it.’ When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on achieving my goal.’

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more exciting the record, the more interest it gets. This gives Jordan a problem. We may complain that achievement often replaces enjoyment in these challenges, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, doing photo shoots, and giving interviews. He has to offer something spectacular, like climbing Everest. ‘And you know what?’ Paul says. ‘If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he’s done with mountain climbing and wants to play basketball instead, we’ll shut this whole project down and go to the gym.’

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they’re not listening to classical music. Most of us can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won’t know who he is. I’ve just started a music degree, but even my classmates don’t know much about classical music. If you don’t know who composed the music, you probably don’t own any recordings of it. The statistics are discouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. So, why has interest in this centuries-old music declined? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who often go to classical concerts, but they are few. Although I’m a musician and play in an orchestra, I’m not a big classical music fan. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. So why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are challenging for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more appealing than a long classical piece without lyrics. Classical music is powerful, but it doesn’t cover issues that interest teenagers. The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families made music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but our lives rarely include classical music. When did you last hear classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new audience members are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why people like classical concerts more in middle age, but I know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They like classical music when they perform, but it’s not their first choice for listening. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Bonnie didn’t mind if she had heard because her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie treated horses well. The horses were well cared for, she noticed immediately. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He seemed lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They can’t be far." The room with the riding equipment was – to Bonnie’s delight – unlocked. Focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she saw. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m not joking, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, a breeze brushing her cheek and making it glow. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian who has become famous for his music. He has released several successful songs. But how did a relaxed surfer become a star on stage? Cody explains, "I started playing guitar at six and writing songs at seven. But I was also swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted some videos online." These videos changed his life. He first posted a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans loved it and asked for more videos on social media. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was huge.

Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches. But when record labels showed interest, he faced a tough decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a risk by signing a music deal and moving to the US with his family. Cody decided to take the chance. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine deciding your future at 12 or 13?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I'm kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked reactions. "I'm very modest, and I think it's important to stay that way in this crazy world."

Cody moved with his family to the US, leaving one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight, they support him from the background. Cody believes it's important to have a close group of supportive people around you. He admits, "Sometimes I worry about how my decision affects my little brother and sister. My brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn't have a regular life. But my family always reassures me that they support and encourage me."

Success in any career comes from being willing to say "yes" to opportunities, even when it's scary. "Everything happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, I'm visiting countries I never thought I'd see and performing for thousands of fans. It's something many people dream of, but I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing I could do it. Not that my grandfather noticed much. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked along the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood processing factory in Milltown. With fragile ice on either side, the dark open patch was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. A boy I didn’t know. I frowned. Unbelievably, he was trying to balance on an ice shelf along the water warmed by the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and reached for my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there – a silver chain my famous grandfather once brought back from a trip to South America. Better than having a famous grandfather is having this chain, which only he, my mom, and I know about. Plus, I have the diary he kept on that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read parts of it before I fall asleep. I patted the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled at me as I grabbed a banana from the kitchen counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful, now.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I headed down the hallway, almost bumping into Grandpa as he stepped out of his bedroom. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going, anyway?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that obvious. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder for me to do that lately. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his sharp words hurt just as he intended. But I took a deep breath and silently counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door shut. Mom appeared with a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself at the moment,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say that he’d always been that way. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he first showed me photos of him in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his bedroom wall, above his dusty expedition medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe someday, my own face in National Geographic. And yet, a part of me still wants to stay devoted to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep it up, even on these cold days!’ I smiled back at her as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before, and it was not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. There was a river that took up most of the scene; it wasn't a river she knew and maybe not even a real one, just a fantasy river. The picture was strange and shapeless – and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was almost invisible, just a hint of green that the eye barely noticed, being drawn into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, no birds, no people; and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice – something too casual, too detached – that showed her excitement. And Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others make sense of them, if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written there. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a strange importance, as if they were somehow meaningful to her, but she didn't know why. And there was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn’t it – I mean, for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he’s going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn’t resist. It’s such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I suppose you can guess his response." Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it’s not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and its own language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. And he said painting’s hard enough work as it is without having to waste time telling every idiot …" "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what the thing means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who came along, they’d never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted her, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa had often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, it was just to say that the muse wasn’t being kind to him today, or that he’d have to be nice to the muse today as he had a difficult part to work on, or something like that. He’d never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being at all. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, having any influence over someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn’t need me to inspire him," she said. "He’s been painting all his life."

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and cut a big piece out of it. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. All I'm saying is, I didn't mean to damage the carpet. I didn't wake up thinking, 'Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.' It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Then later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm very unlucky that way. What I was actually doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! Very small and painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But the thing is, it is a corner cabinet. That's why it's shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom. This is because it's the smallest room in the house, under the roof, and shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the one the size of a broom cupboard is mine. Mum says that when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, it seems I'll be in my broom cupboard for years. I don't really mind; I quite like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the way the roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... That's when it came to me. If I couldn't cut anything off Gran's cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It just seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be quite pleased with me. He is always telling us to 'think outside the box'. And that was exactly what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly 'borrow' things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to be from the Borrowers' point of view, not a human one, which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. In the story, there's a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn't have to act. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn't sit during breaks and had to be sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don't think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren't accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn't allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully conveyed the magic of the books.

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the "can-you-get-me-free-tickets-to-your-dad’s-concerts?" ‘Everything’s going to be fine,’ I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. To leave my old life on the road and with tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet real kids. Like a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so normal. I walk into the school’s main office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule please,’ I tell the school secretary. ‘Name?’ She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. ‘Desert McGraw.’ ‘Desirée?’ she asks, leaning closer. ‘Desert,’ I repeat. The secretary seems confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types ‘McGraw’ on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One second, it’s printing,’ the secretary says. Then she hands me the sheet. English Literature, first period. Cool, I like that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, so I wouldn’t look lost. When I get to the door, I hear the teacher already calling names. ‘Aurelio Gonzalez.’ ‘Here.’ She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. Dead giveaway. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher pauses. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says hesitantly. ‘Here.’ The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. ‘So why’d you move here?’ my new friend asks. I have lots of choices here. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? ‘We need a change, Desert,’ he said, ‘and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.’ Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they pick South Beach Sounds, a studio near the sand? ‘My dad had to relocate,’ I tell her. Yes, lies work better. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. ‘Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.’ And she doesn’t seem to care. Excellent.'

Text: 'Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what being an American teenager is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and stay unnoticed because being average is not enough anymore. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and not having big ambitions is seen as laziness. "People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers have these days. We have lots of homework, tests, extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life," says teenager Kristen Loose. Despite these pressures being normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist, often spread by the media. You know the ones: lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-absorbed. While there is some evidence of these traits, putting the whole generation in this category is not fair, some say. "Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV and using our cell phones," Loose says. Loose believes this is mostly wrong. She admits to keeping her cellphone close most of the day, but not just for fun. It's not just for texting friends; it's a tool that teens use to make their lives - and the lives of those responsible for them - easier. Students today are expected to have immediate access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can look like a cell phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can now take their work with them and do homework anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they could be listening to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities no longer stop at the school gate but need 24-hour attention from already busy teens. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often end after midnight. Their schedule is full of school, after-school activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to get up and do it all again the next day, with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. The US National Sleep Foundation surveyed American teenagers and found that about 20 percent get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Moreover, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are sleep-deprived. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen thinks that after all her activities, she gets about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 is not much. Olsen rarely spends those hours on social media or TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteer work. "I think the stereotype of teenagers is that they only care about themselves and their own interests," Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen says her favorite part of the week is volunteering. "I love helping others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community during the week." In 20 years, who knows what the stereotype for teenagers will be, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be another generation of students who are changing the world, all before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, east of the Sierra Nevada mountain range. This group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth's surface. It's a science project with a twist: part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These occur when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by an enthusiast from a nearby state, inflates the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some run and track its path with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There is quiet and a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside and look at the clear sky, hard to believe it's just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I watch a boy climb into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure decreases, and the balloon expands until it pops. A parachute helps the equipment land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who notes they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is becoming familiar with this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘It's important to remember that these students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is simply a way of life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s also a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountain ridges. And it’s one more adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance. 'My younger brother was really into dinosaurs, a phase many kids go through, but I hadn't. I helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in the field. It amazed me, and I knew I wanted to pursue it,' she says. I wonder what support she received since Palaeontology wasn't a common career choice for young people then. 'I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist,' she laughs. 'Matt Cornelius was already famous, even though he was young. I was nervous, worried he'd think I was just a kid bothering him with questions. But he was patient and willing to listen, which made me feel more comfortable,' Chloe explains.

I ask her about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV. Chloe frowns. 'Movies like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. While I appreciate the interest, the few palaeontologists shown in films are often stereotypes. We're either seen as eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks, which isn't accurate. Films don't show the reality of our work,' she says. I ask her to elaborate. 'My job is very varied. I dig up dinosaur bones, spend time in labs analyzing fossils, and write for scientific publications.' Although it's not a daily task, Chloe also communicates scientific findings to the public when possible. She takes this role seriously. 'There are many misunderstandings about science. Some colleagues avoid this challenge to focus on research, but I think it's important. I like reaching out to young people to show them all aspects of science. Talking about dinosaurs can excite them about the natural world and help them understand other scientific ideas.'

The TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs was a chance for Chloe to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She notes that the program's creators knew their stuff, and she was there to advise if needed. 'I didn't have much to correct, just small things like the size or shape of dinosaurs, and ensuring they existed in the same time period. We attracted audiences of all ages because we've learned so much about dinosaurs recently. The ones in this program are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They're the most life-like ever shown,' she says.

Why does Chloe think dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a research focus? 'I think they appeal to the explorer in all of us. We are drawn to the unknown and the idea of discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us there's still more to discover. Palaeontology is like time travel,' she concludes.

Text: 'I’m just going to say this once: when you’re traveling by car with your family, even if you’re six years old, you probably know you’re not ‘there yet,’ even as you keep asking ‘Are we there yet?’ And anyway, once you get there, it’s not ‘there’ anymore, is it? It’s ‘here’. So if you think you might be ‘there,’ you should ask ‘Are we here yet?’ And I’m sure no one wants to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. I mean, really – what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather be relaxing in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs you haven’t seen before, listen to music, or do puzzles you’ve had for a long time, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there’s mum or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, or changes the radio station and temperature to whatever you want – basically, they keep everything running smoothly like a concierge! Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – usually my younger brother, Tim. Like putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can’t do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it’s his other foot, and then a hand, and soon he’s in my space and we start fighting. The driver and co-pilot reach back to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. And the beautiful scenery, full of history, continues to pass by. Soon after, I’m trying to read, and I feel something – a breeze on my arm. But the car’s not going fast and the window’s not open. So where’s it coming from? My brother is in the next seat, quietly blowing air onto me. He’s on his side, not touching me – so he’s found a loophole. Just breathing? What’s the problem with that? The anger rises. Tim gets yelled at, there’s more swerving. Then slowly the chaos calms down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has developed ways to deal with us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yup. We’re here. Get out of the car.’ ‘But Dad. We’re still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.’ ‘Oh, well, then maybe we’re not there yet.’ That kept us quiet for a while. You can tell when you’re finally ‘there’ when you see the adults get out of the car and go as far away as they can from the kids who have annoyed them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet.'

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope customers will love the experience and return. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to communicate with each other."

The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame by North American designer Matt Leacock, is about solving global problems together. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He recalls, "When I played that with friends, we felt scared. There were highs and lows, and everyone felt good, win or lose. I wanted to create something like that."

Leacock's love for board games started in childhood. He was often disappointed by games, so with his uncle's help, he redesigned them. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel added more storytelling. Leacock says, "It's like an electronic game where you develop characters, get new rules, and the world changes. It's an unfolding story."

The growth of video games has surprisingly helped board games become popular. Video games have made playing games normal. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone has at least one game they like. More people are open to playing games now."

Video games once offered social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But as online multiplayer games grew, players became physically separated. Some people who enjoyed video games started looking for games to play with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, games are something to share in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with setbacks. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced him. He was 12 when he first heard a contemporary song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't what he wanted to do for life because it was too much hard work.

At 17, Jamie left school to pursue a music career. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to be a musician, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano daily. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Jamie found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't come. He feels he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK, helping new artists start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that aiming for chart success is okay. He asks them, "Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He believes in writing songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well.

Jamie speaks openly about wanting to write hit songs that reach number one. He is not arrogant; he simply knows he has a talent for writing hits. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. When he works in the studio, he aims to write the best music of the next year, not just what's trendy. He wants to create classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online but probably unknown to people who don’t watch online videos of bike stunts. He is a ‘street trials cyclist’ - he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys know who he is, and we stop a few times as older people come to tell him he’s ‘an absolute legend’. After seeing his skills, I agree. Even though I was doubtful at first, I’m impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and I can’t always believe he’ll succeed. But when I praise him, he seems uninterested. Despite his online fame, Tony says he’s a reluctant celebrity. ‘I find the social side hard. I see the value of connecting with fans, but I prefer doing things rather than talking about them.’ This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. ‘This technology lets people like me make a living,’ he says. ‘Sometimes I feel everyone is focused on cameras or screens, and part of me doesn’t like that.’ However, he’s not complaining. Through his videos, he earns well from what would have been just a hobby in the past. I’ve learned from interviewing top athletes that two important factors turn a keen child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These may be more important than talent and help in persisting despite failure. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what were easy but new obstacles for him. He just got up and kept trying until he succeeded. Tony isn’t always seen as a hero. Some say he’s reckless and takes unnecessary risks. He says, ‘Those who say this may be concerned but don’t know much. They probably haven’t ridden a trials bike and don’t understand the sport. They don’t know the technical details and don’t realize I get expert advice to minimize risks.’ Tony is careful about the risks he takes. ‘People are different. Some never get scared and shouldn’t do these sports; it’s wise to know the dangers. The rest of us are either unable to overcome fear or can. I’m in the group that feels fear but finds a way past it. I’m not addicted to risk and spend hours planning. Sometimes I ride around to get in the right mindset before a new stunt. I know I mustn’t lose my nerve before I jump. If I fully commit, then I’m fine.’

Television presenter Helen Skelton has completed many dangerous challenges for charity, like running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she already had some circus skills, she quickly found out that high-wire walking was very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t realize how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then came an hour of exercises, with another hour after my day practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to keep a positive attitude: if I was nervous and started shaking, so would the wire!" On the day of the actual challenge, it was windy, and Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she admitted afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" The experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it for a holiday trip to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. A serious fever left him in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or the journey home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using an exciting tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but nothing about their night activities because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope will give us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat. The work is very hard.
